message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of no menarche and recent onset of headaches suggests the possibility of an underlying medical condition such as a brain tumor in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland. Pelvic ultrasound can help evaluate for any congenital or structural issues with the reproductive system that may be causing the delayed onset of menarche. MRI of the head may be necessary if the ultrasound is negative or if there is suspicion for an intracranial lesion. Serum estradiol and testosterone levels may be useful in evaluating for hormonal imbalances, but pelvic ultrasound is the best initial step in management given the patient’s presenting symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lack of menarche suggest primary amenorrhea. The pulsating headache occurring on one side with nausea relieved by ibuprofen suggests migraine. The elevated blood pressure suggests an underlying condition. A pelvic ultrasound is the best next step in management to evaluate for any anatomical abnormalities that may be causing the primary amenorrhea. MRI of the head would be indicated if there were neurologic findings present or if the headache was not typical of migraine. Serum estradiol and testosterone levels may be useful in further evaluating the underlying cause of amenorrhea but would not be the immediate next step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that she may have migraine headaches, but since she has not experienced menarche, it's important to rule out potential underlying gynecological issues. Therefore, a pelvic ultrasound is the best next step in management to assess for any potential gynecological abnormalities or causes for her delayed menarche. An MRI of the head may be considered if there are concerns of neurological or intracranial pathology. Serum estradiol and testosterone would not be the best initial tests in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age, lack of menarche, and headaches suggest she may have a pituitary tumor causing hypogonadism and headaches. A pelvic ultrasound is the best next step to evaluate her reproductive organs and exclude pregnancy as a cause of her symptoms. MRI of the head may be needed later for further evaluation, but pelvic ultrasound is the first priority. Serum estradiol and testosterone are not sensitive or specific enough for evaluating pituitary function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms include headaches and absence of menarche, which could suggest a problem with reproductive system or pituitary gland. Pelvic ultrasound can help visualize the reproductive system and detect any abnormalities. MRI of the head is indicated for suspected intracranial pathology. Serum estradiol and testosterone may be useful in evaluating hormonal production, but they are not the best next step in management for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest migraines, not necessarily related to her lack of menarche. Pelvic ultrasound should be performed to assess for any anatomical abnormalities and evaluate the possibility of primary amenorrhea. MRI of the head may be necessary if there are neurological symptoms or signs of intracranial pathology, which are not present in this case. Serum estradiol and testosterone are not indicated at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible migraine, but also raises concern for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can cause delayed menarche, headaches, and hypertension. Pelvic ultrasound is the best next step to evaluate for PCOS. MRI of the head or serum estradiol would not be useful in this case, and serum testosterone would be indicated if there were signs of hyperandrogenism on physical exam (such as hirsutism, acne, or male-pattern baldness), which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and blood pressure suggest a possible hormonal imbalance. The absence of menarche and normal breast development suggest problems with the reproductive system. Pelvic ultrasound is the best next step to assess for any ovarian or uterine abnormalities that may be affecting her menstrual cycle. An MRI of the head is not the most appropriate initial step as the patient’s headaches are likely due to hormonal issues rather than neurological ones. Serum estradiol and testosterone levels may be useful in evaluating hormonal imbalances, but pelvic ultrasound should be done first.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible hormonal imbalance or pregnancy, so a pelvic ultrasound would be the best next step to evaluate for any abnormalities in the reproductive system. MRI of the head is not necessary unless there are additional neurological symptoms. Serum estradiol and testosterone may be helpful but are not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, combined with absence of menarche and high blood pressure, suggest the possibility of a medical condition affecting the ovaries. Pelvic ultrasound can help confirm the diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome, which can cause menstrual irregularities and headaches, as well as high blood pressure. MRI of the head is not indicated based on the patient’s symptoms. Serum estradiol and testosterone levels may be helpful in diagnosing other conditions, but are not the best initial step in this case.
